column10: I have been playing this game since I was a child. For as long as I can remember, this game has been a comfort game for me. I highly (and I mean HIGHLY) recommend this game to anyone!

It's a great, timeless classic.

Don't go and buy the "definitive edition," thinking you will get an updated spin on this classic game. The  "remaster" fundamentally changes the game and tampers with its legacy. If the "definitive edition" was so great, why did Microsoft up the price of the classic while heavily discounting their "improved" version?

PS: Also, it looks like they went and seemingly removed pricing history on AoE 3 Classic, so people don't notice that it used to be sold for a lot cheaper. I bought this game before December 2022 for way less money without it being on sale, however there is now no pricing history for steam before that date.

Age of Empires III: Complete Collection delivers a mixed bag. The single-player campaign offers an enjoyable journey through history, but the multiplayer aspect lacks the depth that has defined the series. Despite its shortcomings, the game's visual appeal and engaging campaign make it a worthwhile addition to the Age of Empires franchise. Players seeking a robust multiplayer experience might find themselves longing for more strategic layers ingame.

Pros:
Graphics. It's a great looking game, particularly considering that in a few years, it'll be old enough to drink in most countries.

Cons:
Zoom disatance. Even at the greatest zoom distance, it still felt like the buildings were right in your face all the time.
Price-tag. It is, at the time of writing a 16 year old game, yet the price tag still reads 37€, almost twice what the much better Age og Empires 2 DE costs, and ond 3€ cheaper than the much more recent AoE4. And as I've yet to see it on sale (of any kind), I cannot in good concience recommend it.
Bugged. Multiplayer is not working, and my understanding is that with the next game in the series out, it likely won't ever. At launch it asks for Activation Keys that Steam does not provide. I haven't found that this interferes with the game itself, but it's still annoying.

I'm middle of the road on this AOE (age of empires) game, The idea its self is a good one however the implantation of it was bad. AOE 3 is more about who can amass the most cannons and cannon fodder with out running out of resources 1st. They are ways around this if you are lucky and fast with making a ton of troops to rush and keep rushing yet only a few of the empires can do this most rely on a cannon/troop mix to win. The AI is very meh once you have learned what they like to play and that is all dependent on the nation. I tend to play this game on the hardest settings and can still easily win since the AI never really changes the tactics much. I can say it is a fun little experiment they did that dose let you have a bit of fun massing cannons and red coats (the ships in this one is kinda bad with nothing to unique about them)  I have not played multiplayer so can not comment on that end of the game-play. Over all this is more of one you get just to play the single maps and not really for the story or the aspect of fun more of a time killer/try.

It wasn't the AoE game that many expected. Not just a copy of the old ways that the AoE series offers. Some new decisions are excellent and interesting and some are questionable in the best-case scenario.

I like the new period of time that developers took! I like new heroes and their opportunities(not just units with a unique name and more HP like it was before).

Yes, it's not the old AoE games, but it's good to have the new point of view for RTS on the whole.

Worth trying? For sure, it is! At least to see the changes they made, and to try something new, as well as to try the new story campaign!
It's still the best RTS after all these years.

This is a great refresh on the series after substantial lag from AEII to this. Upgraded graphics, unit control, and combat are all excellent over the admittedly grainy original. The campaign is more episodic with clear ties over the eras presented. The somewhat unfortunate trade off here is the campaign has become a bit campy, with somewhat cartoonish graphics and more elements of an RPG-type story line rather than an empire building RTS. That said, still an excellent overall game, and one that is worthy of multiple replays.

Without further ado - It's quite a good, fun game! Pretty easy to beat on moderate difficulty. If you enjoyed playing AoE II, the complete collection is worth it. Although it's not the same thing as II, the game has a fine vibe overall and will keep you hooked. Have fun!

I have hundreds of hours on this game from before steam was even a thing. The variety of units, buildings and maps makes skirmish after skirmish very enjoyable. Some factions have more variety than others, but all feel fun and rewarding to play in their own way.  I have only ever dipped my toes into other Age of Empires games, because I always found myself drawn back to this one, even while playing Age of Empires IV.

The campaigns were enjoyable but pretty simple and linear, with no real creativity allowed to progress through them. But they are fun short historical fiction stories that are a good way to learn how to play the game.  If you are looking for a simulation game this is not really it. The game focuses entirely around the strategic battles and resources essentially only exist to build your army.  Overall 10/10. One of the best strategy games I've ever played, and I consistently find myself wishing more games had the depth of Age of Empires III.

The most underrated Age of Empires game that was dumped on by older Age of Empires fans who felt this game was to mainstream or to simplified or didn't require as much strategy and felt to easy. They were way to harsh as Age of Empires 3 may not be as complex as 2 but 3 is an amazing game in it's own right. Age of Empires 3 campaign is based less on historical events and battles that happened and was more like trying to tell a historical fictional story with real historical figures and factions like the Knights of St. John and the Ottomans. The Asian Dynasties is the best expansion in the whole Age of Empires 3 package as it has the most game play mechanics and content. I highly recommend this game and everything that comes with it! This is a perfect Age of Empires game for newcomers who may be intimidated by the pacing and mechanics with the first two Age of Empire games excluding Mythology. Age of Empires 3 is an amazing third installment and one of the most graphically beautiful games I've ever seen. The music and soundtrack is also so beautiful and calms you.

In the age of empires, we both did meet,
On virtual lands where warriors compete.
With muskets and canons, our armies would clash,
But in this pixelated world, our love did amass.

In Age of Empire III, we found our delight,
Building colonies and waging epic fights.
Yet amidst the battles and strategies grand,
It was your smile that truly took command.

You were my ally in times of war,
Together we'd conquer, that's for sure.
But when the sun set on our virtual land,
You held my hand, and I knew you'd understand.

As the ages passed and civilizations grew,
My love for you, my heart, it knew.
No matter the epoch, no matter the quest,
With you by my side, I felt truly blessed.

So here's to our love in this digital age,
Built on teamwork, laughter, and courage so sage.
In Age of Empire III, our love did bloom,
A timeless bond, forever in the game's room.

Great strategy game! Actually "Age of Empires" series are my favourite and the only strategy games I enjoy. I'm not really into strategy games, but these series are a pleasure to play. They are worth your while.

How is it that this is in many ways BETTER than the "Definitive Edition"?? 

Why is it in some ways a *far* more graphically and sonically engaging, entertaining spectacle when destroying enemy bases? in a release made 13 years before the latest one? why did they take out the buildings blowing apart? why did they take out that rad 'ZZT ZZT ZZT' arrow flight sound effects; why does the newer version cost over ten times the disc space than this? WHY, DAMMIT?!?

I think I'll always prefer AGE III over all the others. even II. it's just the one made most for me. time period, block-unit production, the weirdness of the card system that pissed me off at first but now is totally legit . . . who knows why. it's just in my DNA. 

I LIKE Age IV, but damn, man -- they used to make really FUN games. you can customize the towns for each of the different cultures you're working your way through. the game loads into it, making a real attachment with both the game and your favorite faction. it's awesome. 

still like DE, but it's really missing a few things that are baffling to think were left out. on purpose. (my cynical side says modern corporate sensibilities thought the old-style chaos was "too vicious". too vicious for a game where you end each match blowing absolutely every innocent farmer away with canons. just a theory, but if not . . . but why leave it out?)

ah, who knows. get the DE version, probably, if you've not played the game. it's often on sale for five bucks. this version isn't. but I really do prefer some things DRASTICALLY over DE. which is a bit weird, when you think about it.

Age of Empires III is like that time you tried to throw a fancy dinner party in the 17th century, but accidentally brought a modern-day microwave as a gift for your host. As you're juggling conquistadors, indigenous tribes, and ox carts, you'll find yourself wishing you had a "Send Pizza" button for instant diplomacy.

When I introduced a steam locomotive to my colonial-era buddies, they looked at it like I'd just summoned an alien invasion. It's a bit like playing time traveler, if time travelers had a knack for causing unintentional chaos.

But hey, amidst the confusion and cultural misunderstandings, there's a certain charm to watching your musket-wielding soldiers try to figure out how to use a telephone booth. Just remember: if your colony collapses, blame it on the fact that you didn't invent the smartphone in 1602.

Age of Empires III: Where history meets hilarity, and your empire's success hangs on whether your settlers can grasp the concept of indoor plumbing before they discover gunpowder. 10/10 would introduce anachronisms again.

Age of Empires III is a remarkable real-time strategy game that holds a special place in my heart, as I've played AoE2 since childhood. It's a game that successfully combines historical accuracy, strategic gameplay, and immersive visuals to create an unforgettable gaming experience. It's a nostalgic journey that builds upon the foundation of its predecessor, offering familiar mechanics with exciting new additions. The seamless transition from Age of Empires II to Age of Empires III feels like coming home, while the enhanced graphics and improved gameplay mechanics take the experience to new heights. It's a testament to the series' longevity and the joy it has brought me throughout the years. Age of Empires III is not just a game, but a cherished part of my gaming history.

As a long-time fan of the Age of Empires series, I was thrilled to revisit the past with Age of Empires III (2007) on Steam, and I must say, it's a classic that stands the test of time. This real-time strategy (RTS) game offers immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, and rich historical detail that makes it a must-play for fans of the genre.

One of the standout features of Age of Empires III is its gameplay. The game offers a perfect blend of resource management, base building, and strategic combat. Players can choose from different civilizations, each with its unique strengths and units, and embark on a journey through history, from the colonization of the Americas to the Industrial Revolution. The gameplay is addictive and challenging, with a variety of missions and campaigns that provide hours of replayability.

The graphics in Age of Empires III are impressive, even by today's standards. The game features stunning visuals with detailed environments, realistic animations, and breathtaking particle effects. The attention to historical detail is remarkable, with accurate representations of units, buildings, and landscapes that immerse players in the time period.

The sound design is also top-notch, with an epic and immersive soundtrack that enhances the gameplay experience. The voice acting is excellent, with memorable performances that bring the characters to life and add depth to the story.

The game's multiplayer aspect is a standout feature. Playing with friends or other players online adds a new level of excitement and challenge to the gameplay. The competitive multiplayer mode allows players to test their strategic skills against others, while the cooperative mode allows for teamwork and collaboration in completing missions.

The game also offers a wide range of customization options, from choosing different difficulty levels to modding the game with user-created content, adding to its replay value and longevity.

The developers have shown dedication to the game's community, with regular updates, bug fixes, and expansions that add new content and gameplay features, keeping the game fresh and engaging even after years since its release.

In conclusion, Age of Empires III (2007) is a classic RTS game that delivers immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, rich historical detail, and a vibrant multiplayer community. Its addictive gameplay, impressive graphics and sound design, customization options, and regular updates make it a must-play for fans of the series and the RTS genre. Highly recommended!

Hey guys, if you're a fan of real-time strategy games, Age of Empires 3 is definitely worth checking out. This game takes the classic gameplay of the previous Age of Empires games and brings it to the colonial era.

What I love most about Age of Empires 3 is the new and improved graphics that really bring the game to life. The gameplay is also incredibly immersive and challenging. You must build and manage your own civilization, train troops, gather resources, and engage in epic battles to conquer your enemies.

The game also features a wide variety of civilizations, each with its unique units and abilities. This makes each playthrough feel fresh and exciting, as you can try out different strategies with each civilization.

Overall, if you're looking for a real-time strategy game that's fun, challenging, and historically rich, Age of Empires 3 is definitely worth a try. It's a game that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

[h1]A good game, but nothing grand.[/h1]

- The nations don't feel as generic as in the AoE 2 but the map and army scales are smaller. It plays more or less the same as the previous games, with some smaller tweaks. E.g. you can now train up to 5 soldiers at once. Graphically the game looks very good and the battle animations, especially when attacking buildings  or ships, are great. That said, the game feels mediocre in comparison to AoE2 or AoM.
- The campaigns have interesting scenarios but the story is very childish and historically inaccurate for the most part. Not to say that AoE has ever payed too much attention to historical accuracy. (Quite the opposite.) There are some scenarios that depict the historical events but even those are tweaked so they would fit the made up stories. Ensemble studios probably wanted to repeat the success of the AoM campaign, but that one was full of monsters so it wasn't that big of a dieal. While fighting russians in apalachians during the early 17 century, and selling it as history, goes a bit over the line. Or fighting the Ottomans in the Caribic. There are many idiotic things like this but these are the most notable ones. 
- The expansions are good, with unique playstyles for the new nations.

P.S. I can't undersstand why they have named japanese mortar "morutaru", as the japanese would pronounce it, but rickshaw, which is originally a japanese word is still spelled rickshaw.

The multiplayer is fun because you fail. The players in multiplayer are so competitive and passionate about their methods of victory you kinda feel like you need to reflect this nature. Sure, when you start you will be horrible and probably kicked off of games because you will probably drag the team down, but when you slowly build up from being this poor player into a gamer that can match your potential with the other games gives a feeling of triumph. 
That feeling makes me still want to play the game.

In this game, one doth assume the role of a great leader, charged with building and maintaining an empire. One must gather resources, train soldiers, and engage in strategic battles to emerge victorious.

The graphics of this game are commendable, with stunning landscapes and realistic depictions of the various units and structures. The soundtrack also doth transport the player to a time long gone, with music that is fitting for the era.

The gameplay, while challenging, is engaging and well-designed. The player doth have the freedom to choose from different civilizations, each with its unique strengths and weaknesses. The campaign mode also doth offer a compelling story that is both educational and entertaining.

However, this game is not without its flaws. Some may find the gameplay to be too slow or repetitive, and the AI opponents may at times seem too easy to defeat.

Overall, Age of Empires 3 is a game that doth offer an immersive and enjoyable experience for those who art fans of strategy games. The game is a worthy addition to the series, and those who art seeking a game that combines history and strategy shall find much to enjoy in this title.

Age of Empires 3 is a fun and engaging real-time strategy game that offers a lot of content and replayability. The game has a variety of civilizations to choose from, each with their own unique units and abilities. The gameplay is deep and strategic, with a good mix of military and economic decisions to make. The game also has a robust multiplayer mode, allowing you to compete against other players online.
One of the standout features of Age of Empires 3 is its campaign mode, which follows the story of various civilizations throughout history. The campaigns are well-written and offer a good mix of story and gameplay. The game also has a number of new features, such as home cities and cards that allow you to customize your civilization and armies.
The graphics in Age of Empires 3 are excellent, with detailed character models and beautiful environments. The game's music and sound effects are also top-notch, adding to the atmosphere.
One downside to Age of Empires 3 is that the game can be a bit overwhelming for new players. There's a lot of content to take in, and the game doesn't do a great job of easing you into things. That being said, the game has a helpful community and there are plenty of resources available to help new players get started.
Overall, Age of Empires 3 is a fun and engaging real-time strategy game that offers a lot of content and replayability. Its

I really like this game. It has the options of gold, wood, & food one needs to earn or find to build some sort of big town out in a wilderness area. AND, there are also cheat codes for those who just want to trounce everyone. The only problem is, that as one goes along, one can earn only 20 extra products to super strengthen one's town. In the other version with "the War Chiefs", Indian tribal villages, one can earn 25  extra products to make one's town stronger. The problem in that game is that the Indians give up too easily on every level up through moderate. While I like to win I like a bit more of a fight. Once I get to the hard levels it seems like my armies react slow or not at all. The enemy walks right past them & no one moves like they do on other levels. The enemy attacks & my armies attack back but the cannons do not react to the fighting right away; or they seemingly get confused & can't figure out which way to go. Everything has to be micro-managed, which is ok in most cases. But, imo, there needs to be a single toggle or some such, where tightly packed troops spread out. There may actually be one but I haven't found it yet. There is one in AOE2. The other thing is, my individual armies attack without being prompted, & march right into deadly fire when I want them to march close in front of the guns & rockets. I use the stop toggle but they don't listen for long. I line up 2  lines in front of the cannon & they tend to group up  again with any movement, even when in separate groups. They will not stay in the 2 lines I've place them in. I don't need my armies charging into another army who's guns are set up to eliminate them while my cannons decide they need to turn into their faster movement modes & then reset a few seconds later. There can be many shots fired into my armies & at my cannons before they can reset. At other times they will move in ready mode going halfway across the country. It's slower of course, but they are ready for a fight right away. Why they usually won't do so in a BIG fight, is the problem.
Overall I still like the first game & second game version of AOE3. The Oriental level is too confusing to me. I've tried it several times but can not figure out how it's supposed to work like the other two levels.
 Just as an aside I like playing the AOE2 game as well. It is simpler. And, while the figures still tend to wander off, or like ten armies go out & attack a single enemy soldier, it is still fun for me to play. I try to separate them, but during a battle it is too difficult to continually keep micro-managing them to send just 2 or 3 of my
armies after a single enemy soldier. I've tried some of the newer 3-D kinds of battle games & am not that impressed with them. Mostly because they end up giving only a limited view of whats going on & one has to continually be switching to other angles to see if someone is coming on your flank when all of my concentration is on trying to separate my armies & big weapons & keep them from bunching up.  Thus I have only a few actual games. Buying others only to find out that they are not what I like is too expensive for my budget.

I've played this game for hundreds of hours offline and before I even got Steam.
Ever since I first was introduced to this game at the age of 12, I've been a massive fan.

At one point in my life, I had no real internet - and this was my go-to game to make me feel happy.

Revisiting it is like riding an old, comfortable bike.
It's like a good friend that never lets you down.

While games today are incredibly complicated, with ever changing metas and constant groaning as new bouts of content are added or missing - Age Of Empires III is a complete package and well worth the price.
While it is missing a few quality-of-life features that could bring it into the new age - it's a solid experience that can give you hours upon hours of enjoyment with or without an internet connection.

7/10
Age Of Empires III is a Good game.
It will never let you down.
While other games tie you to an online service, have complex narratives, demanding gameplay, and clunky shortcomings - this one holds true and continues to deliver a timeless experience with great replayability 15 years later.

AofE was one of my favorite games of all times...although I stopped playing it when I discovered I could beat the campaigns simply by building a castle as close as possible to the enemy...no matter the opponent, strategy, story - whatever; especially the Genghis Khan campaign, whose civilization was based on movement!

However

What I enjoyed about the AofE was the careful, rewarding resource management, and I could see the developer attempting to balance this with combat...but coming down more on the resource management aspect.

Then we come to this iteration of AofE, which proves that the rot which exists in AAA franchises existed then - namely, the simplification of games to appeal to a broader market.

If I could depict this as a percentage, I would say resource management is a paltry 10%, and the rest is flashy gimmickry.

As one reviewer pointed out - one or two farms provide limitless resources...which in a way I would understand because the developer intended for the player to then concentrate on combat

HOWEVER

Combat, with essentially limitless resources, is essentially moshing a mob of units at a target.

There is no finesse or skill required; thus, the simplification of combat for the mass market extends to the combat also.

Thus, this game attempted to please everyone, but in the end pleases no one.

Shameful.

8 out of 10 Misfits will enjoy playing this game.

I am a huge AoE fan, played every single one of them since they first came out on disc back in my childhood.  Although it says I've only played 2.6 hours of the game, that is ONLY my time playing it on steam as I wanted to see if there was any difference between that version and the microsoft version (which there is not).

If you love any of the other AoE games, or any of the other games in the genre than you will completely love this game.  There is so much to do, so many ages to live thru, and so many cultures to explore.  The story missions are great, and the sandbox games are super for learning and upping your knowledge, but where the game shines is the multiplayer and the ability to "create" your own game within the game itself.

The modding abilities of this game and the ability to create whatever your mind can think of (within reason of course) is a great addition and will prolong this games life by so much.  (And it already has)  The graphics are great, the sound is spot on for the age you are in, and the fighting is a pleasure to portray even though you are only creating the units and sending them off to fight for you.

I have loved these games and they will always hold a special place in my heart.  I completely recommend this game to anybody who enjoys base building, rts games, and learning about different cultures from ancient times.

This one or the definitive edition?
Although DE advanced a few steps forward it still won't take the place of the classic AOE3 for me. 

DE has added more paid content, which is not that bad in terms of civs, but cosmetic microtransactions are making their way into the game and it just doesn't feel... right. Sure, that doesn't break the gameplay but it also has performance issues and more color saturated, cartoonish graphics that I'm personally not a big fan of. 

This is a game I casually play because of nostalgia so my opinion is naturally biased towards this edition. If you're a singleplayer enjoyer then I can wholeheartedly recommend that you get this one (Still playable with friends tho). The "attractive" things from DE asides from its new civs I'd say is that it is cheaper and has official servers running, in case you're more into multiplayer with randoms. Both editions can be modded but DE has official support for that.

Yeah, AOE3 is not as popular as AOE2 but it's still fun in its own way. It's always worth a try

My history with this title is a little more complicated than its predecessor. Originally received as a gift when I was a child from a caring relative in the days of disc-installs and Windows Vista (and then finally 7). My family was lower income, so a computer to run it perfectly was wishful. But I did my best to play it and get some enjoyment out of it with the computers available. I found the models and styles to be a bit WEIRD at first, new looks and all. My toleration of aesthetics grew with my mastery of the game. I developed an early game infantry rush tactic that worked out excessively well against AI. Anyways. Time passed and time passed. The years went on, but the title remained in its various forms. I eventually came to own the title on Steam. So here we are, more than a decade later. Not the perfect title, but it stands.

I like using control groups when moving the right group of people to the correct area.  Switching between control groups helps me manage a lot of the micro.  I definitely always use Control group #1 for my explorer and control group #9 for my town center.   If i have a civ whose explorer has a pet I always use control group #2 for the dog.  I like to put a healer on control group #4 .  Scout goes to control group #3.  Calvary go to control group #7 artillery to control group #8 ranged infantry go on control group #5 and regular melee go in control group #6.  that is how my game unfolds.  early in my game I sometimes send forward villagers out in control groups #7 and #8 and hold stray units in control group #3.  to sum up, using the control grouping systems like i described really speed up micro managing all my empire.  I usually eye ball the map to go about managing my military productions but maybe sometimes I do group a large number of similar structures with a control grouping system during an economic boom.  P. S. Love this game...played many many games and hasn't changed.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

A fun rts game, even with it being the black sheep of the franchise. I know I'm in the minority but I actually prefer it of AoE2. Why?
-Less villager micro, the main reason I can't get into AoE2
-Each civ is capable of many different strats thanks to the card system. Some cards are capable of huge effects like transforming units into other units or decreasing the cost of upgrades or even giving upgrades for free
-Trading posts provide "free" resources, encourging expansion
-The game centers around a time of history that isn't talked about very much, especially the asian dynasty expansion. The time period allows an interesting mix of melee and gunpowder units.
-Any special effects a unit has are told to you through its tool tip or stat page, something AoE2 doesn't do (at least when I played). 

Some of the negatives?
-Some units are extremely overpowered. Shipment only units are infamous for this.
-It costs way too much to advance to the last age. And its almost like the devs knew because there are no new cards in the imperial age.
-Some civs are missing units and I don't really understand why. Germany for instance is missing both musketeers and grenadiers. And while I like their unique units I don't think they're strong enough on their own to justify that.
-Low unit cap on navy units. Can make naval battles a bit boring. Some cards help a little bit with this.

And why play this version over DE? More stable for one thing. And you actually have to unlock new cards which adds more replayability imo. Lastly, and this may just be me personally, but I just don't feel comfortable supporting DE after they decided that partaking in revisionist history was more important than fixing actual issues with the game. Terrible things happened in history, and we acknowledge it so we can learn from it. Trying to cover it up is self-defeating.

A wonderful game, an absolute classic. The Home City deck system was, and still is, an innovative addition to the classic AOE gameplay, and the native tribes and trading posts made each map feel that much more alive. But it's a crying shame that this game has been rendered obsolete with the release of the Definitive Edition, which has better graphics, extra factions, oh and it's also $20 cheaper for some reason?

To be clear, I LOVE this game. This game was my childhood, and if they counted the playtime on my old PC my hours would be in the thousands. But I cannot recommend it, because Ensemble Studios no longer exists and the current owners of the AOE franchise don't seem capable of updating the classics to modern standards.

The franchise that never disappoints, the fourth installment (AOM included) and yet to have a less than average game in the rooster.

Age of Empires games have always introduced new things with every release, and this one does not shy from introduced a whole lot more than ever before, making it almost feel like a completely different game.

I've always thought that modern/colonial age games would make no sense in an RTS format, as we have sound breaking bullets that travel faster than you can devise any plan or strategies on the fly, but, Age of Empires III begs to differ, there was so much new to offer.

The varying civilizations and how greatly they offer not only in building/unite models but also gameplay features. And don't even get me stared on the Asian Dynasties and Fire and Shadow DLCs, literally games inside of a bigger game.

I still get dozed in by how amazing the graphics look in this game. For a game from 2008, it's insane how the visuals have aged, the lightning, water shaders, and destruction physics were an experience in and of themselves.

AoE3 is a game I can come back to time & time again and I always have a good time. Dumping in 12 hours in a day as a kid and coming back years later to have just as much fun is not something I can say about any other game. 

I love the fast pace of the games, where seconds can make or break your matches (This is also nice for someone who doesn't have hours to kill and wants to get a quick game in). The mechanics of the game are very unique compared to the former AoE titles, especially the home shipment mechanic. It makes you a bit more invested into each civ; it's nice to mix and match shipments to find an optimal deck for your playstyle. In addition, each  of the 14 civs play so much differently so I rarely get bored when experimenting with civs. 

My only beef with it is some civs need rebalancing (I'm looking at you, France & Japan) because they are so much more powerful than any other civ if in the right hands.

All in all, 10/10 game that I probably will be playing for a long time to come.

The fact that I don't recommend this version of Age of Empires 3 is down to one thing: [b]Age of Empires 3 Definitive Edition[/b] exist, which is better in every way.

DE has better graphics, updated balance and UI, and working online multiplayer that doesn't require a patch because Microsoft lost control over the ESO domain. Plus it has more content. Not much, but still. I know that some players will sell the fact that you have to grind for the home city cards as a positive, but I don't. I hated that grind even back in 2007, because if you play multiplayer, you start with a disadvantage compared to other players, purely in terms of available options for your homecity. Having everything unlocked is a big positive and encourages trying different civilizations. And even if you want to grind, you can still do that for cosmetics.
And last but not least, there is the price: Age 3 (2007) is 37€ (or your regional equivalent), while Age3DE is 20€. Microsoft keeping this version on sale and not just quietly removes it is a good move, but the price wasn't great to begin with, and with DE in existence it makes absolutely no sense.

The only reason were I can see this version to be useful, is if you want to play a mod that isn't compatible with DE. But even then, wait for a deep discount.

Unlike it's predecessors, AOE3 is a game that went wrong in so many ways and despite some enjoyability, the only reason i am not recommending it is because of it's limited gameplay and take away experience. 

AOE 3 isn't the worst game, nor is a waste of money if you get it on sale, however it lacks the depth of the last two entries before it and doesn't feature nearly enough maps and mechanics to live up to the others in reputation and sales. 

AOE3 does have this.. the Card system, something i am really fond of and would have like to see more of in previous games. These bundles of joy are truly awesome and offer a dynamic and rich playthrough for anyone who enjoys RPG aspects in an RTS game. 

I do also have to compliment the developers on the trade routes and native settlements that really put an emphasis on holding certain areas of the map despite vital resources elsewhere. Their bonus are somewhat overpowered but awesome. Having trade route victory seems silly but makes sense for the time period, for colonialism in the new world.

Love the game.  Couple adjustments should be made, including zoom levels, adjusting max population, etc.  A lot of the limits seem to be a way to keep needed computing power down, but those should be optional.  500 pop limit, double the zoom distance, and this would be as good as AOEII.  Overall, awesome game.

I struggled to grasp the mechanics of this game when I bought it because it was the brand-new twist of a game series in which little had changed fundamentally for a decade, but also suspiciously resembled other existing games (its sister Age of Mythology and also Rise of Nations). Now, having played the game seriously in preparation for the latest version, I find this a superb challenge and an excellent adaptation of the original AoE engine, and what I think of as the "Return of the Jedi" of the original AoE game series. Consider it a fine end to the old ways and the bridge to a shiny new one for the next generation.

In summary, not worth the cost.

.To kick off, this review will be purely personal because there is a lot to say about this game and most other critics tend to 
  overlook this game cause of the standard that the 2 first games of the saga drew. 
 I would not say this game is the best of the series, but to be honest is one game that should not be forgotten. Its 
  mechanics   are totally different from the others and they add a fresh perspective to the game. The shipments are a plus 
  for this game, adding a new factor of surprise which, depending on the civilization, can change the fate of the battle. 
  Another important  but  understimated mechanic are the treasures. At first they seem to be trivial and not really 
  determinant but when   resources are at stake in the early game they can become essential for players to start making a 
  huge difference or preparing an early rush.
 Some say that this game can become monotonous for some players and that its civilizations are not well-balanced. To that   
  I personally believe that though the game can become that way when mastering a civ but there are thousands of ways of    
  actually winning a game, like trying different combinations with your teamates or developing your own new strategies. As   
  for the second aspect there are some civs that are better than other but this always depend on the situation, there is not   
  a civilization which can completely defeat another by itself. There are some units that can be overpowered, like the french   
  cuirassier or the japanese ashigaru musketeer, which can be both considered the best normal units of the game without 
  taking into account super special ones. They are very powerful by themselves but against the right units they can be 
  pretty weak. All civs and units have their purpose and functionality and they are great at it but used in the wrong 
  situations they become pretty much useless. Due to this I can say that this game is great, independently of your civ skill 
  , critical thinking and a complete analysis of the whole game can make you win almost every game regardless of the odds.
 Though the game itself offers a vast and varied types of campaigns, after completing all of them the game can become a 
  little bit dull to the ones looking for a challenge and battles based on historical events. For this there are lots of original 
  mods and creative scenarios created by the community throughout the years.
All things considered, Age of Empires 3 has nothing to envy its brothers, having played both the sequel and the pre-sequel   
  I can finally state that the 3rd one was special for me. Therefore my almost 400 hours I spent enjoying this game. I would 
  not really reccomend it to everyone because it is not a casual and friendly game or at least that is not the way the devs 
  built it to be. It is a hard and demanding RTS, there are no time for breaks during the battle and so that is why I would 
  only reccomend it to RTS fans and history-lovers, because believe it or not the game also offers a lot of insight into the 
  different historical backgrounds of every civilization.

played it for years, expert is crazy tough, must use niche tactics to win, individual games lack a cetain lasting appeal, it's sort of a rush to get the edge on others through advancement and trying not to get wiped out, once you push past a certain balance though it all goes downhill and makes end game kind of boring. still, pretty fun game. incredibly complex Edit: very complex, military unit counters at surface level are rock paper scissors. at higher difficulties, multitasking, knowing your civ is crucial, micro-movement exploits help a lot, past the surface level of rock, paper, scissors, it gets much more complicated i.e. units that hard-counter other units get hard-countered by the same units in different circumstances. archers hard counter samurai, but if you get samurai up close, bye-bye archers, they get ripped apart. I wish AOE4 had something a smidge more historically modern than 3. ah, but warfare tactics can vary so much past around the 1800's it might be hard to replicate with decent accuracy and manageable flow rate for an rts. still I feel more drawn to this AOE than others because of how historically modern it is.

Age of Empires III is a great game despite being inferior to its predecessors. Its gameplay holds up despite being over a decade old; and while the graphics aren't incredible, they hold up far better than many games from the same era. Like Age of Empires II, there are hours upon hours of content to be had across the campaign, sandbox, and multiplayer modes. New game mechanics like the home city system and streamlined resource gathering add a nice twist to the formula. The strategy of the game hasn't changed all that much as the AI is still easy to funnel into choke points and will rarely change its strategy. Ultimately, Age of Empires III is an easy recommendation though I would recommend either Age of Empires or Age of Empires II more. 

+ Graphics have aged well
+ Excellent RTS gameplay
+ Intuitive game mechanics
+ Good music
+ Streamlined game mechanics
+ Interesting home city system

- Mediocre campaign
- AI is easy to manipulate
- Zoom level can't be adjusted

Best Real-Time-Strategy of all time! I spent thousands of hours since the game launch (i.e. before purchasing the Steam Version) I love the effort Ensemble Studios put in to build a piece of history into a game for fun! Simple to play easy to get in, hard to master. You can play as the ever strong European civilizations like conquistadors from Spain, the tribal and speedy raiders of Sioux tribes and the ever majestic and honorable Samurais of Japan! 

Original Campaign:  Vanilla and cohesive story-line focuses on Morgan Black (Act 1), John Black (Act 2) and Amelia Black (Act 3); characters that you want to support and play from start to finish!

Warchief Campaign: Not my cup of tea, if you like American Revolution or playing as Tribesmen then you might like it.

Asian Dynasties Campaign: Comprises of 3 campaigns which are in order; Japan, China & India. 
Japan is based on Shogun Wars; China focuses on a fictitious explorer and his friend travelling around the seas and India is based on India's fight for independence against their British Colonial Master. All are fun and unique in their own right!

Multiplayer: I did not play much as I am mainly a solo player. Not applicable.

So many Civilizations to choose from and master. Get it when on sale & re-live the classic moments of Age of Empires 3!

Age of Empires III is more of a step to the side rather than a step forward in the Age of Empires series. The game play has been revamped to be quicker, in addition there is far more a focus on combat. Exploration is a nice mechanic that was added to reward players who like to scout the map with various "treasures" which provide various resources and even additional free units. Pathfinding has been majorly improved and combat A.I. is far better than it was in previous games. Due to the game changing more than I liked personally, I consider this a step sideways than a step forward, as it doesn't quite add entirely new mechanics but rather, it changes or reworks old mechanics into "new" ones.

Overall I would certainly recommend this game to anyone interested in a Colonial era RTS game, but I'm not sure I would recommend it outright to a hardcore Age of Empires fan.

This game is superb! Definitely an improvement from Age of Empires I and II! There's lots of maps you can pick with beautiful scenery, different nations each with their own leader that automatically quote funny taunts at you in-game, as your enemy or ally (for instance, if you destroy the Portuguese's town center, their leader, Henry the Navigator, can say,"You have razed my town center, you filthy swine!" or Queen Isabella can say, "You play to rough. I would like to stop now."), and, unlike, Age of Empires 1 and 2, there are only 3 types of resources in this game: Food, Wood, and Gold. In Age of Empires 1 and 2, the resources were Food, Wood, Gold, and Stone, but Age of Empires 3 doesn't include stone in this one. If you've played Age of Empires 1 and 2, you'd know that you have to build a mill at food, a lumberjack at wood, and a mining camp at stone and gold, just so your villages can drop off the resources. But in this game, you don't have to do any of that! You don't have to build any annoying buildings at resources just so your villagers can drop stuff off, you can just tell your villages to harvest the resources, and they'll just simply do it, without needing any building to drop off their resources! So much better! :) 

And not only are the graphics in this game much better than Age of Empires 1 and 2, so are the campaigns! In Age of Empires II, just about all of the campaigns require you to be an enemy of Jerusalem, which is just shocking. But in this one, the campaigns have extremely exciting, fictional stories. I don't like the Japanese, Chinese and Indian campaigns, but the Black family campaigns are awesome! There's 5 parts to the Black family campaign (each part has a bunch of levels), and each part stands for a generation of the Black family:

Part 1 is about Morgan Black, a Scottish Knight, in search of the Fountain of Youth. He runs into enemies and friends along the way, like Elizabet Ramsey, a pirate, Sahin, an Ottoman general, Alain Magnan (who Morgan takes orders from), and Spanish conquistadors. 

Part 2 is about Morgan's grandson, John Black. A villain called Warwick kidnaps John's uncle, Stuart Black, because he knows Stuart is one of Morgan's Black's sons, and might know the whereabouts of the location of the Fountain of Youth's water. So John and his best friend, Kanyenke, set out to try to rescue Stuart, and hunt Warwick down. Along the way, they meet George Washington, the United States' first president, and receive his help. John is married to a Native Indian, Nonahkee (who is actually Kanyenke's sister), and at the end of Part 2, she has a son, Nathaniel Black, which leads into Part 3. 

Part 3 is about Nathaniel Black and his army of natives fighting back against the British and especially the vicious Hessians, who take their orders from the cruel Colonel Kuechler (pronounced Kooch-ler). Kuechler even kidnaps Nonahkee, Nathaniel's mother, and Nathaniel and his uncle, Kanyenke, set out to rescue her. 

Part 4 is interesting, because the protagonist is not a man this time, but a woman - Nathaniel Black's daughter, Amelia Black. It starts with Amelia Black owning a railroad company. She meets a sinister Frenchman, Pierre Beaumont, who says he knows of a cave with gold, and will let her have a share of it. Amelia agrees, but, unkown to her, it's a trap, Beaumont is only leading her there to kill her. Kanyenke, the native from Part 2 and 3, knows this, though, and gets there in time to reveal Beaumont's plan to Amelia, and who Beaumont really is - the leader of the Circle, who wants the Fountain of Youth's water. Beaumont flees into the caves, and that's what Part 4 is about - Kanyenke, Amelia and her friend Cooper chasing Beaumont down, to bring him to justice, find out if the Fountain of Youth is real (only in a game :D), or just a myth, and, if it's real, get to the water before Beaumont does (Amelia says at one point, "What will the world be like if Beaumont lives forever?"). Along the way, they run into Simón Bolivar, who agrees to help them with Beaumont if they will help him and his people be free of the Spanish.

And part 5 is my absolute favourite, every single level is really fun to do. The story is about Chayton Black, Amelia Black's son. Amelia Black married a Native Indian (you never see him in part 4 or 5, Amelia just mentions him when she visits Chayton, in Part 5), so Chayton has native Indian blood in him. Amelia has retired from the railroad company, and Chayton takes over. He meets an old man, Billy Holmes (who becomes Sheriff later on), and they work together to defend colonists from Sioux attacks. The Sioux attacks deeply concern Chayton, so he goes up into the mountains to meet with the Sioux's leader, Crazy Horse, to find out what is going on, and try to stop a war from starting. As you go through this story, you find out why the Sioux are attacking, and who really started all this fighting. Eventually, Chayton is faced with the choice to either ally with the Sioux, or with Sheriff Billy Holme. What will he choose?

Purists of the Age of Empires II type may dislike the random treasures and native villages which create artificially important (and immovable) positions on the map, but I think they make this a different game from Age II in a way that detracts from neither.

TLDR: Made obsolete by Age of Empires III Definitive edition which includes exclusive DLC, better resolutions support and better AI.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/933110/Age_of_Empires_III_Definitive_Edition/
Where have so many hours of my life gone?! This game can make an hour long skirmish feel like 15 minutes.

"In my opinion, this is one of the best games of its genre. A large variety of maps, civilizations, units and interesting gameplay; it is never boring. It is worth its money (for an excellent price)."

And after the release of the updated version, my opinion has not changed. This game has a special spirit, atmosphere, realism. These are not cartoonish textures and bright graphics, this is something completely different. Playing with friends brings unforgettable pleasure and memorable moments, sometimes you are convinced of the accuracy of the phrase "never underestimate your opponent."

The fan community after 16 (!!!) years after the release lives its own life, creates mods (I suggest you trying Wars of Liberty, which allows you to play as one of 43 civilizations). The huge array of community maps are easy to install, and the level editor makes creating them easy.

I started this game, not understanding the basics, and lost to bots even on easy difficulty, I abandoned it several times, but ... This only inflames interest in the game, in new strategies, research, tactical actions. It will appeal to both experienced players and beginners who find it difficult to decide on the first game of the genre.

Often the game is simply underestimated against the background of the second part, which is very wrong, because BOTH games deserve attention and respect. Age of Empires II won the hearts of players (quite deservedly), but personally to me it seems slow and difficult to master all technologies and strategies, game sessions are long. The third part is simplified in some aspects (as example, you have no need in creating fields for mills), but this does not make it worse.

Talking about the topic of single player campaigns, there are 54 interesting scenarios ( including warchiefs and asian dynasties add-ons). In amount of scenarios, Age of Empires II takes gold, but AOE III shouldn't be underestimated. You'll enjoy playing them or even creating your own campaigns.

Graphic effects are not far behind from the technologies of 2005-2007 years, the game still looks fresh and has flexible graphics quality settings (for both 32/64 bit systems).

Definitely buy this game, call your friends and enjoy it! Age of Empires III will not let you get bored :)

When I first met this game, I was studying in primary school, I would open the second game of the series as soon as I got home. Then one day we went on vacation to Ankara, we were staying at my aunt's with my family, I found this game while I was picking up my brother-in-law's work laptop and I used to play it so much that my brother-in-law was almost fired because he couldn't do his job. I couldn't find that game, and I couldn't play the second game of the series because I spilled coffee on the computer at home. I searched everywhere for this game but couldn't find it. When I was little, I would sleep with dreams of this game, and sometimes I would see other people and envy and cry, but when I had a computer exactly 8 years from now, I bought and installed the game. Once I couldn't even play easy, now I play in master mode and I participate in tournaments when appropriate. Even if your dreams are far away, remember that you have a pair of feet.

It can be almost impossible not to compare AOE3 with AOE2 and the debate is in many ways understandably hardcore.
Both are historical RTS games with a 'base building' mechanic and each game offer campaigns based on the era they represent (though the historical accuracy of the former is quite head-tilting).
When compared with other historical RTS games from other developers and RTS games of other genres (fantasy, SCI-FI), in my opinion AOE3 offers an interesting game-play.

STRENGTHS: The GRAPHICS for the time along with a unique HOME-CITY look for each of the 8 civilisations (compared to the abundance allocated for AOE2) are its strongest points. The TRADE and NATIVE posts and 'playful' yet 'taunting' AI DIALOGUE, along with an explorer (with his own witty dialogue in their own native language) that can collect some nice early game rewards from TREASURES (G0-GO Spanish wardog) while you manage your exploration age colony brings a 'NEW WORLD' sentiment to the game.

     "Aanvallen!" (Attack) - Dutch explorer - in game.

WEAKNESSES: However, the CARD system (though rewarding)can be unbalanced and the AI unlike AOE2 fails to adapt to what you throw at it. Certain AI also fail to live up to their namesake and are awful allies (Sulieman fails to capture his historical counterpart's military prowess and seems to set about only collecting resources).  Simple ROCK-PAPER-SCISSORS dynamic could push away players for 'dull' uncomplicated strategy. 

     "This food is almost as good as my own chefs could cook." - Napoleon Boneparte - Emperor of the French

Each AI CIVILISATION has noticeable strengths and weaknesses that creates for a very skewed game-play! Between the booming defensive Dutch, infantry spamming Russians and Cuirassier crusading French, I find each team offers a unique way to play with their own obstacles and unique skills to contend with.

I enjoyed this game when I played the CD-ROM copy years ago. 
I will admit parts of the game are dated, certain controls are stiff and the graphics can be clunky at times, but as a fan of RTS games I will forgive dated graphics for enjoyable gameplay. 
There are two main components; single player and skirmish/multiplayer.
SIngle-player is always fun, you follow a story of a family line from the age of exploration into the industrial era. Missions can have varied objectives and unless you have forced limitations can easily be solved with build a large army and attack. It does a good job of teaching you the general game mechanics and you meet several hero characters with different abilities.
Skirmish mode allows you to play as several nations each having special units that favor a certain playstyle. You can add features/customize a port-city which is fun to show progression along with building a deck of cards to activate in game. Portugal has some of the best light infantry in the game while China has a funky system of rather than buying a unit you buy a group of several units (unless you use a fort). Naval combat is very simple, with only a few ship options, yet there is something fun about the daring small ship with very vital forces sailing through the waters as larger ships blast each-other at the same time.
The main drawback is the unit population. There is a cap of 200 and foot units count as 1, but cavalry can easily take up 3 per unit, and artillery takes up even more. Unlike AOE II where you could have as a cap of up to 500 or more which allowed for some large armies, you have to build you economy and an army with a smaller batch. 
Overall, if you want a fun, relaxing game with a very slight learning curve that has a smaller scale then other installments I would recommend it.

Great strategy game that has an intriguing "historical" narrative.  The characters are well developed and nicely ties in with the War Chiefs. Lots of exciting chapters, many various terrains from swamps to mountains, (War Chiefs builds upon it and then some!). I find myself returning to replay every now and then: building new colonies, trying different strategies in building,  and choosing various cards. The "rewards" of choosing cards is a really nice bonus. This is an excellent game to  teach youngsters to "think / plan ahead" -- multitask -- prioritize. This game also demonstrates how vital "common working people" are to society. On a scale of one to ten, I would give this game a solid ten. I hope that many more genres will be added as time goes on -- and -- perhaps current chapters to be expanded.

TLDR: Great game, but buy the Definitive Edition.

[u]Introduction[/u]

I have been a fan of the Age of Empires series ever since the first game was released in 1997. Despite my fairly low play-time on the Steam Aoe3 Complete Collection, I played the original AoE3 release (and expansions) for hundreds of hours before purchasing on Steam for a nostalgic fix.

[u]Game Basics[/u]

AoE3 is (IMO) the best game in the series. It has an engaging and interesting single-player campaign (if slightly clichéd). I personally found the three Asian Dynasties campaigns less engaging, although mainly because they were standalone stories which were not linked to the main campaign narrative arc.

Compared to the previous games in the series, the differences between each civilisation are much more substantial, requiring a different strategy for each - particularly so with the native American and Asian civilisations. This increases the longevity of the game significantly, as you learn the nuances between the civilisations and explore different playstyles. In addition, the rock-paper-scissors between unit classes is much easier to understand and is clearly indicated in the user interface (e.g. 1.25x damage against heavy infantry, 0.75x damage against cavalry etc.).

The home city adds an interesting new dynamic to the series - every action (gathering resources, constructing buildings, killing enemy units, destroying enemy buildings, etc.) earns XP which will in turn permit you to choose civilisation-dependent shipments from the home city (free units, resources, economic bonuses etc.). The XP earned is permanent and unlocks new cosmetics for that home city.

Each civilisation also has an explorer hero unit which is designed for revealing the map and discovering various treasures across the map for a tactical bonus. In addition, trading outposts can be built on trading routes (for resources or XP) and native villages (for unique improvements and units which do not count towards your population limit).

[u] Why You Should Buy the Definitive Edition Instead[/u]

Better graphics are a given. The Definitive Edition also has an improved user interface, and much better multiplayer stability. Further, all of the expansions are rolled up into one coherent version of the game, whereas with the Complete Collection you need to select which expansion you want to play when booting the game.

The single biggest improvement with the Definitive Edition is a change to the way home cities operate. In the Complete Collection, you could create as many home cities for each civilisation as you liked but once the city was created you could not change its name or explorer name. Each home city had to be designated for Supremacy or Deathmatch, and could only be used in that game mode. Further, single player home cities could not be used in multiplayer and vice versa. Home city shipments were dependent on level, so someone playing with a low level home city would be at a competitive disadvantage because they would not have access to the best shipments. This could become frustrating if you don't play exclusively either single player or multiplayer (and/or one game mode).

The Definitive Edition shakes this up. You have one home city for each civilisation and you can change the city or explorer name in the game settings. You do not need different cities from single player / multiplayer and Supremacy / Deathmatch. Most importantly, all shipments are unlocked from the beginning.

There are also periodic limited-time events for the Definitive Edition (much like the AoE2 Definitive Edition), giving you access to new cosmetic items (mods and profile pictures).

The Definitive Edition is simply a more polished and user-friendly experience.

If you liked the other Age of Empire games, you will probably like this game. This time around the game is set in the real world, and you are a colonist for one of the colonial empires at the beginning of the age of discovery. This means you will be settling the new world, or parts of Africa or Asia. The game controls or the game mechanics haven't changed a whole lot. Everything can be done with a mouse. There are tons of menus with clear instructions on what everything does. Instead of fields you get windmills and plantations. You can actual get resources shipped from your home city. And when you level up, you get to choose two upgrade options. Also you can start in a campaign mode or go multiplayer. 


conclusions
fans of the series can get into this without a tutorial, and should enjoy the new colonial setting.

ok, i have tried numerous occasions to enjoy this game... i came from playing AoE2... i had EXTREMELY high expectations. to me, the controls are wonky and not intuitive. that alone ruined my thoughts on the game. it would appear as though it favors a "clicker" play style and not a hotkey. you have to play Russian Roulette with they keys, or at least i did. i found the civilization selection lacking.... over all the game play was just horrid to me. i couldn't play through 3 hours of this game before i uninstalled it. just stick to Age of Empires 2, or even Age of Mythology. I grew up on two games: ao3 and EE2. Aoe3 gets a lot of bad reputation because people are obsessed with age of empires 2. What does this offer that game 2 doesn't? well, every single faction will look different, have different units and most importantly: play differently. Graphics are still good, the style is still beautiful and the gameplay is still awesome. I sunk so much time into this on the dvd version i'm ashamed to admit. Most importantly i revisted it as an adult and it holds up very much like it did back in 2008 when i bought it. 

About the two expansions that come along:

First is Warchiefs. You get three native american civilizations that are very unique and cool. The technology they lack they compensate by new mechanics and pure awesomeness. Aztecs are a bit OP to be and to fight against, but no problem. I love the Iroquois but most importantly i love the SIOUX. it's like mongols. 100% horse army. Mad fun with them. This expansion also bring mercenaries into the game and the option to have a revolution in the last era. Not my cup of cofee but the more the merrier. 

Second is Asian Dynasties: Three very unique civilizations that play in interesting ways. Japan only has 5 units and some weird rules, but that makes for interesting gameplay, India has elephants (need i say more?) and then comes my fav faction of age of empires 3: CHINA. So many unit variation, so many possibilities. it is the hardest to understand yet simply the greatest. Altho they use the controversial Qing Flag, they are awesome in every aspect. 

To conclude: Age of Empires 3 was part of my life for many years, and i may be biased, but see for yourself if it's not worth this much praise. It is, in my opinion, LEAGUES ahead of game 2 simply because every civilization is different. More is not better. Better is better. 

11/10? nah. No rating system would describe this game. 

On a personal note: My three favorite factions are Dutch, China and Sioux. But it has a faction for every single taste. Versatile game that is both amazing in single and multiplayer.

Age of Empires 3 is one of my favorite games of all time, and indeed my favorite strategy game there is, the graphics are stunning for a game almost 15 years old. I love the gameplay, it gives a lot of freedom in my opinion, great civilizations, great music, great maps and the home city customization system and the whole card mechanic is really fun and keeps the player wanting to battle and level more to get those juicy cards! The campaign mode was different from the typical Skirmish Mode but it was really nice! Now for a few of my problems with the game, Skirmish Mode although fun and can provide quite the challenge on a higher difficulty. But the AI can be pretty stupid sometimes, then some really simple things are missing from the game like at the Market why no food for wood trade and vice versa? Why no Imperial Besteiro upgrade for Portugal and the list of small things goes on and on. And for last the glitches, the game can have so many annoying bugs, that till this day haven't been fixed. As for the amount or civilizations and maps, I am satisfied but maybe a bit more options in terms of games rules and maps would've been nice. But overall AOE3 is a fantastic game, and has been one of my favorite games since childhood.

This game is old, but still has booming player numbers. I logged on a Friday night, and there were 967 players online. To put that into perspective, Black Ops 2, a major success in the Call of Duty franchise in 2012 (which had over 100,000 players online at any given time in its heyday), now has about 700 players online on average. This game is from 2005 and it has more active players than Black Ops 2 currently does...

This is testament to how great the game is. From the panicking micromanagement at the start of the game, to the early rushes, to the late game cavalry charges, to the explosive finales within the enemy's base, AOE3 offers matches that feel accomplishing. You look at the clock at the end of the game, and you think to yourself, "No way that was 50 minutes, I felt as though I just started!". AOE3 keeps you engaged THROUGHOUT the whole game, if you feel bored, or are sitting around twiddling your thumbs at any point, you are probably going to lose the match. The graphics are outstanding for their day, and still hold up today. I have never gotten a headache from low quality graphics while playing this game.

This game is also an absolute blast if you are playing with friends, you HAVE to work with your allies in order to win. You will likely have to send reinforcements to your friends' towns against raids, and may have to share resources with each other to keep your team afloat. In my opinion, nothing is better than fighting a losing war and having your comrades literally send in the cavalry to save you, then counterattack with hundreds of troops into the enemy's town... In conclusion, AOE3 is a brilliant, masterful, real-time strategy game that I would 100% recommend to everyone interested in the genre.

TLDR; AOE3 is fun, engaging, and popular. Why haven't you bought it yet?

I strongly recommend NOT to buy this game, if you want to play online with others. Read along to find out why.

First of all, whenever you try to join any multiplayer game you'll get the error message 'Failed to join game' and there is no working solution to this on the internet or on any AOE3 community. I tried all the solutions I could find like adding the eso.com host details on your host file, port forwarding and none of them worked. 

However, using a VPN called 'Windscribe'  worked. But it reduced internet speed from 180-200 mbps to 5-10 mbps and I couldn't join any game again as I was repeatedly kicked out because of low ping

And there is patch called 'CC ESO patch' from AOE3 support which is supposed to fix this problem. But none of the other players has this patch so it creates compatibility issues and again you won't be able to join any game and you'll see the message - 'CRC Mismatch'

I played AoE3 ever since i was a kid — played it pirate tho, no internet or gaming stores in a 100km radius, so excuse me. I'd say i have over 1k hours total in this game (in fact i got level 50 in every civ in singleplayer, all legit, no cheats).
That being said, i can give some opinions on this game. They are very controversial, and will enrage everyone around — specially AoE2 fans. 
Important to mention: i played a f*ckton of hours in both games, and i reviwed then both as negative. It's just that one is way more negative than the other.
Also, i got to rank 24 in multiplayer (from 50) and i got there with a victory ratio way over 50%. So i'm not complaying of multiplayer because i'm a clueless noob.

1. AoE3 game design >>>>> AoE2 gamedesign
Several things included in AoE3 make the game superior to AoE2. But the nostalgia glasses, the never fixed bugs and the lack of balance support eclipsed the new features. AoE2 was a mess at lauch too, but the devs simply decided to not fix stuff in this new game. 

2. Civs are better designed in AoE3 than in AoE2
all civs have unique techs, unique features, sometimes more than 1 unique unit, etc. Ottomans are completely different from any other civ, same as japanese, chinese, indians, french, germans, russians... You get my point. The more "alike" are portuguese spanish and british, but there are a lot of factions, so you can kind of excuse.

3. card system can be fun and enrich the experience:
You can select the cards before the game, so you can customize your colony. You can have a economy focuse, military focused, defensive focused or naval focused deck, and the cards actively can change how you play. Combine this with the unique civs, and you can play in any way you want. Except...

4. You can't play how you want:
5 minutes in a game and you lose. There's no tactic you can do, no counter you can pull. You can only do the same thing your enemy does, except faster. AoE3 is as close to a "solved game" as a modern game can get: the recipes on how to win a game are set in stone, and not playing by these recipes result in total anihilation. Overpowered rushes 'impossible' to react to are very common, and can only be countered by a even earlier rush (which you can't do with all civs, effectively turning the games into mirror matches to avoid these broken strats insta winning).

5. Broken units & techs;
I could complaim about the cuirassier HP, but i wont. I will, instead, complain about instant training of units. Due to bad coding, the player can literally train instantly cavalry or infantry. Love or hate balance/realism, this is broken and should be fixed asap. It wrecks the game flow and completely invalidates suprise attacks — why keep a standing army if i can train 40 dragoons to defend my base from a surprise attack that got me completely disprepared? 
Here is the deal tho, THIS makes the units broken. Cuirassier are good units, compensated by their cost and the time you need to get then. Instant training just negates the waiting time lol.
(guess what, this isn't fixed in the definitive edition).

6. Historical Accuracy:
Campaign is fantasy. They say it at the very beggining. But even AoE3 fantasy campaign is more historically accurate than the entirety of AoE2. the Thirteen colonies, the Armada, the native onslaught, the expansion to the west... The background very well portraied in AoE3. Meanwhile, AoE2 fails to portray the 100 Years Wars or the Reconquista in a meaningful way.

7. Campaigns:
The japanese and India campaigns are awesome and really do teach. If you are buying to play singleplayer, then adquire the game in a deal (non americans websites offer singleplayer-only copies 100% off). The fantasy ones are meh, i didn't liked the ones with native americans. It doesn't have as many like AoE2, but the AoK nerds who hate on AoE3 campaigns don't even know who Joan of Arc is.

AoE3 is a terrible game to get into today. It was excusable before 2016 or something, but not today. Multiplayer is a mess never to be fixed. If you want to play AoE3 multiplayer, try AoE3: Cash Grab Edition, i mean, Definitive Edition. I played the closed beta of AoE3 DE, and i don't recommend it too.
But if it had one entire year focused to fixing these things, the game would be a thumbs up. Unlik AoE2, AoE3 can be fixed (but it wont in the definitive edition, because screw it)

Absolutely wonderful game, Everyone says age of empires 2 was better but I personally disagree. There is a steep learning curve with this game. The expert AI is very easy, but once you know what to do, you will learn enough to be able to beat 7 other expert AI teamed up against you solo. You will be able to play online and have some success if you are willing to learn the unconventional strategy this game requires. You cannot adopt a "Turtle" strategy in this game. It does not work. I love Turtling in RTS games but in Aoe3 you MUST control the WHOLE MAP with walls or units/millitary buildings. Your success relies on gathering the RAW resources not the infinite options like mills or plantations and KILLING enemy settlers to stop them from getting access to those resources and Tradeposts. If you are lucky enough to be the one on the attack then 9 times out of 10 you have already won. If you are defending you have to survive and pray your opponent will make a mistake. You must know a basic build order. Once you understand what a build order is you must create your own, because there is no build order online that is perfect. They only work if play in a certain way so by making your own build order you will optimize your strategy eventually. Make multiple "Decks" and try them out. No civilization is worth playing until you lvl them past lvl 50 so play on easy to get the experience unless you enjoy a headache. After lvl 50 build your deck and switch straight to expert to see what it is like. You will learn that the expert AI actually does not understand the strategy of this game at all and you will have fun. Then try online play. I wrote all this because I absolutely love this game, all 3 of its campaigns, Original, War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties, I love just playing against expert AI to relax, I love playing online with the small but friendly community and i love trying new strategies. I hope that this could be of some help.

The fast-paced, slightly politically correct successor of one of the best RTS games ever. It was one of the last things my father purchased for me before he passed, because I asked for it for Christmas. I like the fast pace that training blocks of units and playing home city cards makes. Rushing in Colonial is always fun. 

There were a couple of politically correct bits in the campaigns added in that I don't like - the stilted narrative of the Turks telling an order of Crusaders to "get with the times", Washington referring to "the holidays" rather than "Christmas" (like most English speaking people before 2000)... it's not VERY annoying. But the main campaigns of AOE3 and The Warchiefs come off as politically self-conscious fanfiction rather than any real story about the periods being portrayed, and it's just not as compelling. The Asian Dynasties campaigns are the best in my opinion. 

Online play is where it's really at. You don't have as many options as AOE2, and deck-building can be daunting for new players, but I remember playing many hours online. Plus there have been several custom maps and RM scripts, my favourite being LoSt (a custom random map where you sail around with an explorer picking up treasurers to get enough wood to make a town center). I had the most fun with Colonial Age rushes and paradoxically no-rush 40 minute matches where you build your base and then have at it. Ah, good times.

It is certainly a good game to me. Just for $30, $25, not $40. Wait until it's on sale.

Remains an awesome sounding and looking game despite its age. Routinely and unfairly criticised and compared to AoE2. Personally, I prefer the simplified resource and tech tree compared with AoE2. Does AoE3 require less skill to manage than AoE2? Yes, but it still has enormous depth and requires careful management of resources just like AoE2 and micro managing correctly early will provide huge advantages over someone who does not (think for example, having you settlers/villagers shoot game so the game moves towards your town centre).

I prefer this over AoE2 because it lets me focus more on the things I enjoy - the combat, large armies and indeed, very unique armies depending on the race. Units and races have genuine strengths and weaknesses. That you can choose your homecity deck provides a level of depth not available in AoE2. Do you stack unit cards to get an early rush? Or do you risk economy or unit strength multipliers that over a longer game provide you with advantages over a unit stacker? Such options! I love getting natives involved for a unique edge (harassing, cannon fodder or whatever you choose) as well as fighting for control of trading posts.

For anyone new to AoE, or indeed strategy games like this, you will not be disappointed as this is the most accessible of the AoE titles available
